skos.definition: Acute kidney injury resulting from decreased renal perfusion without intrinsic parenchymal damage, characterized by reversible reduction in glomerular filtration rate when adequate renal blood flow is restored.
skos.scopeNote: Most common cause of AKI, accounting for 40-70% of all cases; characterized by preserved tubular function

content.title: Pre-renal Acute Kidney Injury
content.summary: Pre-renal AKI is the most common form of acute kidney injury, caused by decreased renal perfusion from hypovolemia, reduced cardiac output, or systemic vasodilation. It is characterized by preserved tubular function and is typically reversible with restoration of adequate renal blood flow.
key_points: BUN/Cr ratio >20:1 due to enhanced urea reabsorption
FENa <1% indicates intact tubular sodium reabsorption
FEUrea <35% more reliable in patients on diuretics
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg indicates concentrated urine
Low urine sodium (<20 mEq/L) reflects avid sodium retention
Reversible with volume repletion or hemodynamic optimization
Bland urine sediment without casts or cells
content.statement: Pre-renal acute kidney injury represents a functional response to inadequate renal perfusion, where the kidney parenchyma remains intact but glomerular filtration is reduced due to hemodynamic factors. Early recognition and treatment can prevent progression to intrinsic kidney injury.

explanation.intuition: Think of pre-renal AKI as the kidney 'going into power-saving mode' - when blood flow decreases, the kidney conserves sodium and water to maintain blood pressure, resulting in concentrated urine with low sodium content. The kidney itself is healthy and working properly; it just isn't receiving enough blood.
explanation.key_insight: The hallmark of pre-renal AKI is preserved tubular function - the kidney appropriately responds to hypoperfusion by maximally reabsorbing sodium and concentrating urine. This distinguishes it from intrinsic AKI where tubular damage impairs these functions.
explanation.technical_details: Reduced renal blood flow activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and sympathetic nervous system. Angiotensin II preferentially constricts the efferent arteriole to maintain GFR, while aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption. Prostaglandins and nitric oxide provide compensatory afferent arteriolar vasodilation. NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors can precipitate pre-renal AKI by blocking these compensatory mechanisms.

definitions_glossary.pre_renal_azotemia: Elevation of blood urea nitrogen and creatinine due to decreased renal perfusion without parenchymal damage
definitions_glossary.fractional_excretion_of_sodium: FENa - percentage of filtered sodium excreted in urine; calculated as (UNa × PCr)/(PNa × UCr) × 100
definitions_glossary.fractional_excretion_of_urea: FEUrea - percentage of filtered urea excreted; more reliable than FENa in patients on diuretics
definitions_glossary.glomerular_filtration_rate: GFR - volume of plasma filtered by glomeruli per unit time, normally 90-120 mL/min/1.73m²
definitions_glossary.blood_urea_nitrogen: BUN - measure of urea nitrogen in blood; elevated in both pre-renal and intrinsic AKI
definitions_glossary.urine_osmolality: Measure of solute concentration in urine; >500 mOsm/kg suggests concentrated urine in pre-renal AKI
definitions_glossary.effective_circulating_volume: Portion of total blood volume that effectively perfuses tissues
definitions_glossary.renal_perfusion_pressure: Blood pressure gradient driving blood flow through kidneys; affected by MAP and renal vascular resistance
definitions_glossary.autoregulation: Kidney's ability to maintain constant GFR over a range of blood pressures (MAP 80-180 mmHg)
definitions_glossary.afferent_arteriole: Blood vessel carrying blood to the glomerulus; dilates to maintain GFR when perfusion drops
definitions_glossary.efferent_arteriole: Blood vessel carrying blood away from glomerulus; constricts via angiotensin II to maintain GFR
definitions_glossary.tubuloglomerular_feedback: Mechanism by which macula densa senses sodium delivery and adjusts afferent arteriolar tone
definitions_glossary.hepatorenal_syndrome: Form of pre-renal AKI in advanced liver disease due to splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction
definitions_glossary.cardiorenal_syndrome: Bidirectional disorder where heart and kidney dysfunction accelerate each other

pathophysiology.mechanism: Reduced renal blood flow leads to decreased glomerular capillary pressure and GFR. Intact tubular function results in enhanced sodium and water reabsorption, producing concentrated urine with low sodium content.
etiology: Decreased cardiac output (heart failure, cardiogenic shock, pericardial tamponade)
Renal vasoconstriction (NSAIDs, calcineurin inhibitors, contrast agents)
Efferent arteriolar dilation (ACE inhibitors, ARBs - especially with RAS)

signs: Flat neck veins (hypovolemia) or elevated JVP (cardiac failure)

imaging: Renal ultrasound: normal kidney size and echogenicity
May show IVC collapse (hypovolemia) or distension (cardiac)
differential_diagnosis: Intrinsic AKI (ATN) - muddy brown casts, FENa >2%
Chronic kidney disease - small echogenic kidneys

first_line: Volume resuscitation with crystalloids (isotonic saline or balanced solutions)
Discontinue nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors if appropriate)
supportive_care: Monitor urine output and fluid balance
Adjust medication dosing for reduced GFR

specific_therapies.hypovolemia: IV crystalloid boluses (500-1000 mL), blood products if hemorrhagic
specific_therapies.heart_failure: Diuretics (if congested), inotropes if cardiogenic shock, consider RRT if refractory
specific_therapies.sepsis: Fluid resuscitation, vasopressors (norepinephrine first-line), source control
specific_therapies.hepatorenal_syndrome: Albumin + terlipressin or midodrine/octreotide, consider TIPS

prognosis.recovery: Excellent if treated early before tubular damage occurs
prognosis.progression_risk: Prolonged hypoperfusion leads to ATN (intrinsic AKI)
prognosis.mortality: Depends on underlying cause; sepsis-associated has higher mortality

learning_objectives: Define pre-renal acute kidney injury and explain its pathophysiology
Identify common causes of decreased renal perfusion
Interpret urinary indices (FENa, FEUrea, urine osmolality) to distinguish pre-renal from intrinsic AKI
Recognize clinical and laboratory features suggestive of pre-renal AKI
Describe the initial management approach for pre-renal AKI
Explain why NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors can precipitate pre-renal AKI
clinical_pearls: BUN/Cr ratio >20:1 is classic for pre-renal AKI but can also be elevated with GI bleeding, steroids, or high protein intake
FENa <1% loses reliability with diuretic use - use FEUrea <35% instead
Response to fluid challenge (improved urine output, decreasing creatinine) supports pre-renal diagnosis
Pre-renal AKI can rapidly progress to ATN if perfusion is not restored within 24-48 hours
In hepatorenal syndrome, FENa is typically <1% despite being a severe form of pre-renal AKI
Always check for urinary obstruction with ultrasound before assuming pre-renal cause

high_yield_topics: Urinary indices interpretation (FENa, FEUrea, urine osmolality)
common_question_stems: Patient with dehydration and BUN/Cr ratio 25:1
Post-operative patient with oliguria and FENa 0.5%
Heart failure patient started on NSAID develops AKI
Cirrhotic patient with rising creatinine and FENa 0.3%
exam_tips: Pre-renal = concentrated urine (high osmolality) + low urine sodium + low FENa
Hyaline casts are benign and can be seen in pre-renal AKI
Muddy brown casts = ATN, not pre-renal

teaching_cases.scenario: 72-year-old woman with vomiting and diarrhea for 3 days presents with oliguria, Cr 2.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.0), BUN 70 mg/dL
teaching_cases.key_findings: Dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension, FENa 0.4%
teaching_cases.management: IV crystalloid resuscitation, anti-emetics, monitor urine output

citations.authors: Kellum JA, Lameire N, KDIGO AKI Guideline Work Group
citations.title: Diagnosis, evaluation, and management of acute kidney injury: a KDIGO summary

citations.authors: Ronco C, Bellomo R, Kellum JA
citations.title: Acute kidney injury

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on KDIGO guidelines and established nephrology literature with strong evidence base

sources.source: KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline for Acute Kidney Injury
sources.relevance: Primary reference for AKI classification and management

sources.source: Brenner and Rector's The Kidney, 11th Edition
